newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission action on tobacco delayed.
newsitem.headline: Commission action on tobacco delayed.

text.p: The European Commission has postponed until next week adoption of two communications on tobacco policy that had originally been on Wednesday's Commission agenda.
Commissioners' cabinets decided the two reports needed further discussion, Commission officials said.
One report is by Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler on the future of EU tobacco subsidies and the other by Social Affairs Commissioner Padraig Flynn on measures to regulate tobacco consumption.

Fischler's paper will address how the EU should target its aid to tobacco farmers. Flynn has been pushing for a phase-out of production subsidies, arguing that they compromise the Commission's anti-smoking campaign.

But officials said the draft communication highlights the economic consequences of that approach, which would put 135,000 farmers out of work with little prospects of diversifying crops because they are generally working on small plots of land.

It says an alternative approach would be to target subsidies at higher-quality tobacco, offer incentives to farmers who give up tobacco growing and double the one percent levy on tobacco subsidies used to finance the EU's anti-smoking efforts.
Flynn's paper will propose new EU initiatives for regulating tobacco consumption in areas such as nicotine content, additives and health warnings.
